message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Non-specific, diffuse pelvic discomfort can be a sign of many conditions, including ectopic pregnancy. The patient denies the possibility of pregnancy, but a serum hCG should be obtained to rule out ectopic pregnancy or other gynecological conditions. Surgical consultation may be necessary depending on the results of the serum hCG or other diagnostic tests. Abdominal CT scan is less likely to provide useful information in this case. Admission and observation should be considered if the patient’s pain is severe or if there is concern for a surgical emergency, but the serum hCG is a more appropriate initial step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with lower abdominal pain and denies the possibility of pregnancy, but serum hCG should still be checked to rule out ectopic pregnancy or other gynecologic emergencies. Surgical consultation or admission may be necessary depending on the results of the serum hCG and further evaluation. An abdominal CT scan is not the first-line imaging for evaluation of lower abdominal pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In a woman of reproductive age with lower abdominal pain, serum hCG should be obtained to rule out pregnancy. If it is positive, then surgical consultation is warranted. If it is negative, then further evaluation is needed, but admission and observation would not be necessary unless there are other concerning factors. An abdominal CT scan may be helpful in certain cases, but serum hCG is the best initial step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the symptoms and the patient’s denial of pregnancy, the most appropriate next step is to check for serum hCG to rule out an ectopic pregnancy. Surgical consultation or an abdominal CT scan would be necessary if an ectopic pregnancy or other serious condition is suspected. Admission and observation may not be necessary if it is a less serious condition or once a diagnosis has been made.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with lower abdominal pain and denies pregnancy, but this symptom could still indicate an ectopic pregnancy or other gynecological issue. Therefore, the next best step is to test for serum hCG to rule out pregnancy before moving on to further diagnostics or management options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with lower abdominal pain and denies pregnancy, making an ectopic pregnancy less likely. However, a serum hCG test should still be performed to rule out pregnancy as a potential cause. Surgery or observation may be considered depending on the results of the serum hCG test. An abdominal CT scan is not the next best step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the patient's symptoms, serum hCG (pregnancy test) should be performed first to rule out an ectopic pregnancy. Surgical consultation may be necessary, but it is premature until a better diagnosis is made. Abdominal CT scan can be considered later if necessary, but initial management should focus on ruling out pregnancy. Admission and observation may not be necessary if a diagnosis is made quickly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with lower abdominal pain and denies the possibility of pregnancy. Serum hCG is the next best step to rule out ectopic pregnancy, which can cause lower abdominal pain and lead to potentially life-threatening complications if not identified and treated promptly. Surgical consultation and abdominal CT scan may be considered depending on the serum hCG results, but they are not the next best step. Admission and observation may be considered if the patient is unstable, but the vital signs provided suggest stability.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy, even though the patient denies the possibility of pregnancy. Serum hCG is the most appropriate next step as it can help confirm or rule out pregnancy as well as evaluate the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy. Surgical consultation and CT scan would not be appropriate as the cause of the pain is still unclear. Admission and observation can be considered after the hCG results are available.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the patient's denial of pregnancy make an ectopic pregnancy less likely. A serum hCG test will help confirm or rule out pregnancy as a cause of the lower abdominal pain. It is less invasive and less expensive than an abdominal CT scan, and surgical consultation should be reserved for confirmed cases of ectopic pregnancy or other surgical emergencies. Admission and observation may not be necessary depending on the results of the hCG test.
